Consulate Guard. beginning to exercise the mind of the Commandant, Muscat Levies, and I think will shortly be taken up by His Highness the Sultan. As you know, guards are very wasteful in troops, and it takes half the strength of the whole .Muscat force 5 to supply the present number of guards, on the palace, bank and Consulate with serious repurcussions upon their training and efficiency. The Commandant cannot for example even get enough men together to do any manoeuvres or useful field training. The question would become even more acute were any more Consulates or banks to open. With regard to the bank, I think the lAiscat Government are trying to get round their agreement whereby they are bound to supply a guard, by substituting armed irregular levies or something. The Palace guard naturally cannot be ^reduced (it is only six men now) or abolished. But, since we no longer }?ave a Treasury here, and have just got rid of the 4^ lakhs of rupees waiting despatch to the Reserve Pank of India, there would not seem to be much of a case for keeping a guard on the Consulate. As there is a Bank, we keep little money on the premises, we have safes which no local thief could possibly break into, and we also have adequate private servants and Government farashes always on the premises. The Consulate is, moreover, situated in a built up area, where no raid or dacoity could well take place. From a point of view of security therefore I can personally see no necessity for a guard at all. The only other consideration is one of prestige, and in my view I can see no loss here either. Owing to the climate the guard has to be mounted right inside the building, and to me the only difference the absence of the guard would make would be the welcome removal of a noisy nuisance. Actually the men are smart and well behaved, and I have no complaint on that score, but care of my body at such close quarters is, I find, rather trying. However this may be, and a successor might take a quite different view, the fact remains that we do not pay for the guard, the .^Aiscat Government have strong reasons for wishing to discontinue it, and if they do tackle us on the point it would be difficult to resist, unless we are prepared to incur the considerable cost of it. Hence I would prefer to write now to the Muscat Government, saying that with the abolition of the Treasury here, we no longer require a guard, and with appropriate thanks for its supply for so long, suggest that^they might now like to withdraw it. % flag would continue to be hoisted and lowered, as hitherto by the senior farash on duty, morning and night. I shall be grateful to know what you think of this proposal. Yours sincerely. His Excellency Sir Rupert Hay, K.C.I.K., C.S.I., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain . ?4B(9 CONFIDKNTIAI). mods.abstract: This file relates to the Muscat Infantry (also referred to as the Muscat Levies), and the possibility of reducing the number of military guards that it provides in Muscat. The correspondence, which is mainly between the Political Agent and Consul at Muscat and the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain, discusses concerns expressed by the Commandant of the Muscat Infantry regarding the supply of officers to the Infantry. With a small number of men available to defend Muscat against possible attack, the Political Agent suggests to the Political Resident that the Muscat Agency and Consulate should offer to dispense with its Infantry guard. Also present as a correspondent is the Sultanate of Muscat and Oman's Minister for Foreign Affairs.
